Award.AwardTitle: Summer Training in Field Research Methodologies, 2015-17

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cultural anthropologists conduct research on a wide range of important topics, including migration, natural resource management, food security, family structure, resilience after natural and anthropogenic disasters, and the social and cultural influences on health and healthcare. The impact of research in these and other areas depends in part on the methodological rigor of anthropological research. Therefore, enhancing the methodological training of cultural anthropologists strengthens the discipline's contribution to basic understanding of the causes and consequences of human social and cultural diversity and to the development of public policy. To those ends, the Cultural Anthropology Program supports programs that contribute to the training of the next generation of cultural anthropology scientists.

This award to the University of Florida supports a community-based methodological training program for graduate students in cultural anthropology. The highlight of the program is a summer field school in Tallahassee, Florida, that will be directed by Dr. Clarence C. Gravlee and Dr. Sarah M. Szurek. The field school provides hands-on experience in all phases of research, from formulating important questions to selecting appropriate methods of data collection and analysis. Students learn and use a range of qualitative and quantitative methods and are closely mentored by faculty instructors. The field school also benefits from a long-term partnership between researchers and community members, so that students also learn about collaborating with local residents and adapting research plans to the needs and expertise of a host community. Over three years, the program will provide intensive training for at least 24 doctoral students in anthropology. The high level of collaboration with community partners also has potential to improve community capacity for research and to enhance public understanding of anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the grant was to enhance the training of graduate students in cultural anthropology. This goal was motivated by a recognized need to improve the quality of methodological training in anthropology. Previous NSF-funded initiatives provided classroom instruction in research design and data analysis. The unique contribution of this program was to emphasize methods of data collection by providing supervised, hands-on training in a real research setting.

We developed an intensive summer training program that ran for three summers, 2015–2017. During that time, we trained 21 doctoral students from 19 universities. Students lived in home-stays with local residents and were matched with partner organizations for service-learning opportunities. Faculty included eight university-based social scientists and six community-based faculty with substantive and methodological expertise relevant to the focus of each summer's program.

In addition, we extended training opportunities to community members and colleagues and students from local universities. Across the three years of the grant, at least 35 individuals took advantage of these opportunities—several of them returning year after year.

The involvement of local community members as faculty and as participants is consistent with the principles of community-based participatory research (CBPR), which guide our work. These principles include creating equitable partnerships between researchers and host communities, promoting mutual learning, and ensuring that research benefits the host community. The participation of community members also enhanced students' access to the community, resulting in a better training experience. Embedding the training program in a real, long-term CBPR collaboration also created a synergy that improved both the training and the research.

The program achieved its primary goal of enhancing the methodological training of a cohort of graduate students in cultural anthropology. The effort had several synergistic effects. First, several students shared lessons learned at the summer training program with peers and professors at their home institutions. Second, as alumni in the program have progressed in their careers, several have used material from the summer program in their own teaching, thereby sharing it with a new generation of students. Third, students formed a network of colleagues who have supported one another in extending the work and launching new projects. Fourth, several collaborations that originated among local partners during the field school persist even though funding for the summer program has ended.

Our contribution to raising the quality of methodological training in cultural anthropology may also impact other disciplines in the social sciences. The training site in Florida featured a high level of interdisciplinary collaboration. A short-term benefit of such collaboration is the development of new projects and ideas, as a result of bringing together faculty members from multiple disciplines. A potential long-term benefit is that students learned about collaboration and are better prepared to contribute to interdisciplinary team science.
